results.title: Two boys and a boat
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The story of how two boys acquire a V.J. sailing boat by joining a club on the shores of Sydney Harbour and the way in which they are taught to sail their craft in safety.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Mason, Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Travellin' round
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Richard Mason, Film Australia and Tourism Australia
results.brief_description: A girl and a boy in a Landrover, a motorcyclist and a continent. These are the most essential ingredients of a travel film with a difference, showing the beauties and splendours of Australia. Featuring Tom Burstall, Adam Plate, Ingrid Tantu, Lloyd Sutton, Susan Hannaford. Music and lyrics by Michael Carlos and Judy Henderson.

results.title: Training champions
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Jack S. Allan and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The methods used by well known Australian coaches including Frank Guthrie, Harry Gallagher and Forbes Carlyle in training present and future swimming champions. Underwater photography is used to show the action of Lorraine Crapp, David Thiele and Murray Rose.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Mason, Jack S. Allan and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Three To Go: Toula
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Part of a trilogy concerning the problems of young people in Australia. Toula is a girl in a Greek migrant family living in a Greek community in Sydney. She wants desperately to be a young, modern Australian, but she loves her parents and they demand a different way of life. In spite of family difference, gradually Toula and her brother establish a blend of Greek and Australian, bi-lingual and bi-social, which provides a certain amount of satisfaction for all concerned.

results.title: Three to go: Michael
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Part of a trilogy concerning the problems of young people in Australia. Michael has to make decisions in the complex but permissive world of today. His friends have followed a relatively straight and narrow path of conformity. Michael has more or less taken this course, but knows that other ways exist. He is prepared to listen to the prophets of change and revolution and is taken on an excursion into the world of the young radical. In which world does Michael belong? Features Grahame Bond. Also available on DVD [319174].

results.title: Three to go: Judy
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Part of a trilogy concerning the problems of young people in Australia. Judy is a young girl who lives in a large provincial city. Like most girls of her age, she longs to get out and see life, to find the fun, romance and adventure. She wants to go to the big city to work. The film shows the last few weeks before she leaves home. We meet her parents, workmates and boy friend. In their comments we discover some of the problems a teenage girl has to face when living in a large country town.

results.title: Telling the World
results.brief_description: As the title suggests, ‘Telling The World’ was made for an overseas audience as was much of the Government film unit’s output. It covers the roles and functions of the Cinema and Photographic Branch and shows Bert Ive filming some of the iconic images he would capture of important Australian events and places. The opening sequence shows a meeting between the Cinema Branch’s Officer-in-Charge Lyn Maplestone and Bert Ive, who appear periodically throughout the film. Ive continued to work for the branch until his death in 1939. The film has been sepia toned, a specialised chemical treatment enhancing black and white film with a warmer tone. Some scenes in the processing laboratory are tinted red. An excellent example of the period’s documentary and innovative filmmaking techniques. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Sydney
results.creator_credit: Joe Scully, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
Presents many and varied aspects of life in Sydney including business and industrial activities, shops and supermarkets, play centres, schools and universities, hospitals and the rapid growth of new buildings. Shows the various recreational choices including football, cricket, surfing, yachting, fishing or just strolling in the beautiful parks and gardens and evening entertainment in the famous Kings Cross with its multitude of night clubs, restaurants and discotheques.

results.title: Surf Beach
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Beaches are part of the Australian way of life. Every year masses flock to the long white beaches to enjoy the sun and the surf; the thrill of riding a wave can be experienced by all on rubber floats, fibre glass malibous, or body surfing. Life saving clubs originating in Sydney and numbering some 230, play an important role in patrolling the beaches and carrying out rescue. Competitive Surf Carnivals provide exciting entertainment.
